711960f.text:
27, 25, 23, 21 West 30th Street, north sice, east of Broadway,
between Sixth and Fifth Avenues.
About 1913.

717388f.text:
The Bijou Theatre, 1237-1239 Broadway, west side, between 30th and 31st Streets. The theatre will be sold and demolished in a
few months.
1913.

717389f-a.text:
1235-1241 Broadway, west side, between 30th and 31st Streets, with the famous Bijou Theatre in the centre. The theatre will be
demolished in 1914.
About 1912.
Brown Brothers.

717380f-a.text:
Broadway, east side, at 30th Street. The building on the S.E. corner, and the Janssen Hofbrau adjoining it, will be torn down within the next six months, and replaced by a four-story building.
January 29, 1928.
P. L. Sperr.

717382f-a.text:
Broadway, at and adjoining the S.E. corner of 30th Street. The corner building and the Janssen restaurant adioining it will be torn down within the next six months, and replaced by a fourwtory building.
January 29, 1928.
P. L. Sperr.

717383f-a.text:
Broadway, east side, from 30th to and including 31st Street. The eight-story building on the S.E. corner of 31st Street is the Grand Hotel; above it is the Hotel Imperial, on the N.E. corner.
January 29, 1932.
P. L. Sperr.

711962f-a.text:
35-27 West 30fh Street, north side, at,adjoining, and east of
the N.E. corner of Broadway.
July 3,1928.
P. L. Sperr.

1509097-a.title: Broadway - 30th Street, west side - looking north
1509097-a.folder: Broadway - 30th Street, west side - looking north, Manhattan, NY

717386f-a.text:
Broadway, west side, south from West 30th Street, show prominently Daly's Theatre. This was opened as Banvard's Museum in 1867, and during the succeeding twelve years, it was known as Wood's Museum and Metropolitan Theatre, Wood's Museum and Menagerie, and the Broadway Theatre. In it's early days it was both a museum and a playhouse, and in the early 70's it was the home of burlesque. Augustin Daly took possesion, remodelled it, and gave it its present name in 1879. It was again remodelled in 1891. The wing to 29th Street was added in 1892. Demolished in 1920, it was replaced with an 8 story office building.
About 1905
H. N. Tiemann, photo
Gift of Urbrock Collection

717381f-b.text:
(1)
Broadway, east side, south from, but not including, 30th Street. The eight-story building on the N.E. corner of 29th Street is the famous Gilsey House, now converted into an office building. Beyond
it is the Hotel Breslin.
June 2, 1928.
P. L. Sperr.
(2)
The same, a year later, including 30th Street. The four-story corner building has replaced the buildings whose demolition was
shown in No. 1.
April, 1929.
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

717381f-a.text:
(1)

717384f-a.text:
Wallack's Theatre, 1220-1224 Broadway, east side, between 30th and 31st Streets. This is one of the famous New York theatres, but
about 1915 it will give way to an office building.
1903.
Iuternational News.

717385f-a.text:
Daly's Theatre, 1215-1225 Broadway, adjoining the S.W. corner of 30th Street. This was one of the famous theatres, during the great days of the stage in New York; it will give way to an eight-story
building in the early 1920's.
About 1900.
International News.
